resources.description: Citation Information:nOriginator:nEarth Science &Observation Center (ESOC), CIRES, University of Colorado at BouldernOriginator:nGeothermal Development Associates, Reno, NevadanPublication Date:n2012nTitle:nArchuleta LineamentsnEdition:nFirstnPublication Information:nPublication Place:nReno NevadanPublisher:nGeothermal Development Associates, Reno, NevadanDescription:nThis layer traces apparent topographic and air-photo lineaments in the area around Pagosa springs in Archuleta County, Colorado. It was made in order to identify possible fault and fracture systems that might be conduits for geothermal fluids.nGeothermal fluids commonly utilize fault and fractures in competent rocks as conduits for fluid flow. Geothermal exploration involves finding areas of high near-surface temperature gradients, along with a suitable u201cplumbing systemu201d that can provide the necessary permeability. Geothermal power plants can sometimes be built where temperature and flow rates are high.nTo do this, georeferenced topographic maps and aerial photographs were utilized in an existing GIS, using ESRI ArcMap 10.0 software. The USA_Topo_Maps and World_Imagery map layers were chosen from the GIS Server at server.arcgisonline.com, using a UTM Zone 13 NAD27 projection. This line shapefile was then constructed over that which appeared to be through-going structural lineaments in both the aerial photographs and topographic layers, taking care to avoid manmade features such as roads, fence lines, and right-of-ways. These lineaments may be displaced somewhat from their actual location, due to such factors as shadow effects with low sun angles in the aerial photographs.nNote: This shape file was constructed as an aid to geothermal exploration in preparation for a site visit for field checking. We make no claims as to the existence of the lineaments, their location, orientation, and nature.nSpatial Domain:nExtent:nTop:n4132831.990103 mnLeft:n311979.997741 mnRight:n331678.289280 mnBottom:n4116067.165795 mnContact Information:nContact Organization:nGeothermal Development Associates, Reno, NevadanContact Person:nRichard u201cRicku201d ZehnernAddress:n3740 Barron WaynCity:nRenonState:nNVnPostal Code:n89511nCountry:nUSAnContact Telephone:n775-737-7806nSpatial Reference Information:nCoordinate System:nUniversal Transverse Mercator (UTM) WGSu20191984 Zone 13NnFalse Easting:n500000.00000000nFalse Northing:n0.00000000nCentral Meridian:n-105.00000000nScale Factor:n0.99960000nLatitude of Origin:n0.00000000nLinear Unit:nMeternDatum:nWorld Geodetic System 1984 (WGS u20191984)nPrime Meridian:nGreenwichnAngular Unit:nDegreenDigital Form:nFormat Name:nShape file

It was made in order to identify possible fault and fracture systems that might be conduits for geothermal fluids.nGeothermal fluids commonly utilize fault and fractures in competent rocks as conduits for fluid flow. Geothermal exploration involves finding areas of high near-surface temperature gradients, along with a suitable u201cplumbing systemu201d that can provide the necessary permeability. Geothermal power plants can sometimes be built where temperature and flow rates are high.nTo do this, georeferenced topographic maps and aerial photographs were utilized in an existing GIS, using ESRI ArcMap 10.0 software. The USA_Topo_Maps and World_Imagery map layers were chosen from the GIS Server at server.arcgisonline.com, using a UTM Zone 13 NAD27 projection. This line shapefile was then constructed over that which appeared to be through-going structural lineaments in both the aerial photographs and topographic layers, taking care to avoid manmade features such as roads, fence lines, and right-of-ways. These lineaments may be displaced somewhat from their actual location, due to such factors as shadow effects with low sun angles in the aerial photographs.nNote: This shape file was constructed as an aid to geothermal exploration in preparation for a site visit for field checking.
